The Japanese kusa, usually translated as 'grass' or 'grasses', actually refers to a wide variety of grasses and other non-woody wild plants.
Of wildflowers and grasses.
A fern.
Japanese parsley.
The open seed clusters of reeds.
Lit. 'horns'.
A kind of seaweed.
A kind of seaweed.
The time when barley ripens.
Associated with evening in Japanese tradition.
At the seaside.
Lit. 'plum rain'.

The Japanese says 'Fifth Month rain', based on the lunar calendar. Rather than translate 'Fifth Month' as May, since the Gregorian month is really June, we use the traditional English word for the period, which is near the summer solstice.
Lit. 'fifth-month darkness', referring to the lunar calendar.
Spring' is sufficient, if context indicates the object, not the season.
Refers to the old custom of starting to wear summer clothes on the first of the fourth lunar month (about 6 May [corresponds to 7 Nov, southern hemisphere]).
A light cotton kimono.
Thin, woven mat.
Lit. 'drying bugs'. After the Japanese rainy season, airing of clothes, bedding, even books, is necessary to avoid mildew and, in the old days, to get rid of insects.
Formerly this implied in a portable tub.
For hay or mulch.
Type of fishing net placed across a stream.
Of people.
May 5.
Most Japanese cities have festivals sometime during the summer, including Shinto observances, a parade with floats, and entertainment.
Tokyo, 15-18 May.
Kyoto, 17-24 July.
Osaka, 25 July.
Lunar 'summer's end'. Last day of June or July, depending on location.
Lit. 'river deer'.
The word is onomatopoetic for the bird's call. Shiki's penname is a Sinicized version of hototogisu.
Old' as in summer, opposed to the younger bush warbler of spring.
Also known as 'crake' in English.
A small fresh-water fish, a delicacy on the order of trout, which is sometimes used as a translation.
First of the season.
Name in a saltwater environment.
The fruit.
Of foliage.
A type of iris, sometimes called 'rabbit-ear iris' in North America.
Sometimes called 'evening glory'; name of a character in Tale of Genji.
The plant.
This is the 'This is the 'natsugusa' of Bash?'s famous poem. Not just 'grass'.
Refers to the oppressive smell.
Refers to the clearing autumn sky.

Sometimes translated as 'pierce to the bone', but the sensation is one of being soaked, as indicated by the etymnology of the verb. Colloquially, the phrase means felt to (or from) the bottom of the heart.
Coloration of the atmosphere from autumn foliage.
That is, the sounds of autumn: wind in dry leaves, insects, etc.
Particularly for the intensity of its blue.
Lit. 'River of Heaven'.
Lit. 'field-divider'.
Lightning at other seasons is 'spring lightning', etc.
Not to be confused with summer season word '
Flowering meadow' gives a better sense of it.
The clear waters of autumn, no longer muddied by summer rains.
High tide associated with the harvest moon.
First buckwheat noodles from the new crop.
The first rice harvested this year.
Usually in a garden, and made of stone or bronze.
Mallets used to pound fullers earth through cloth in a traditional dry cleaning process. The sound of fulling blocks was typical of an autumn evening in old Japan.
Ninth day of the ninth lunar month, about mid October.
Weaver Star Festival, 7th of seventh lunar month, i.e., in our August; sometimes celebrated on our 7 July.
Festival of Returning Spirits, 13-16 Aug, on which Japanese are pleased to welcome the spirits of their dead ancesters home for a day or two.
At Bon Festival.
Refers mainly to the mating calls of the small 'sika deer' (English) native to East Asia. (Other deer mate at various times.)
Japan is the winter home of many birds from the north, and the summer home of others from the south. In autumn the skies fill with birds going one way or the other.
Come to glean the rice left over from the harvest.
Both are members of the same taxonomic family.
See 'returning geese' (kigan), spring.
Coming downstream; see sweetfish (ayu), summer.
A small cicada; the name is onomatopoetic for its cry and includes the word for 'priest'. Meimuna opalifera.
Many named insects are found in summer; this refers mainly to insect sounds.
See also favorite named crickets, below.
Early Japanese poets invented the literary fiction that the small 'ji--' sounds of the autumn night were the cries of worms.
The fruit.
Authorities differ widely on time, some indicating early autumn, some late, some all
Specifically, the red-turned leaves of maples
Refers to the leaves, when they have turned color
Pawlonia, also known in English as 'Empress Tree'. Famous for the sound of the fall of one of its large leaves, a classic symbol of autumn's arrival
Lit. 'fruits of trees'; includes nuts, pods, etc.
Its leaves turn red
Well known for large, fragile leaves which tear in the wind.

From which the poet Bashô took his name. Also called a plantain (unrelated to the plantains of N. America), produces inedible fruit. A poetical subject because of the sound of its broad, fragile leaves in the autumn wind and rain

Refers to
 mature plants.
Of rice.
See 'lotus' (hasu) in summer.
Frequently translated as 'grass blossoms', but includes many other flowering plants.
As with kusa no hana, refers to more than grasses.
The frosted tips of plants and trees.
For the waving silvery fronds.
. Lit. 'voice of the reeds'.
Platycodon grandiflorum. Low-growing plant with moderate-sized, blue flowers
Lit. 'maiden flower'.
Lit. 'little spring'.
Of things.
Of weather, air, etc.

The last day of winter. Features ritualistic chasing of devils out of the house, allowing good luck for the spring (the traditional New Year). Compare the English ritual of opening front and back doors. (Some authorities place Setsubun in the 'observances' category.)
Lit. tree-witherer.
Lit. wind-flowers.
Japanese-style, refers to a pair of quilts placed on the floor for sleeping, the thicker one underneath.
The toy; lit. bamboo horse
Market set up mid-Dec specifically to sell New Year's decorations, toys, and related items. Somewhat like a Christmas-tree lot, but broader in scope
Day 12 of the 10th lunar month, 28 Nov 1694 Gregorian.
Day 25 of the 12th lunar month, 17 Jan 1784 Gregorian.
Used equally for ravens.
Seliola quinqueradiata.
Lit. 'returning flowers'.
A literal translation; for its red berries.
For its red berries.
Which are red.
Falling or fallen.
Often translated 'winter grass', but has a much broader meaning.
Another species, also for its red berries.
In the old calendar spring began on or near lunar New Year's Day (currently celebrated in many places as "Chinese New Year".)
Of the New Year.

In the lunar calendar, the fifteenth of the first lunar month is the night of the first full moon of the year, hence 'Little New Year'. Still observed on modern 15 Jan by some as the end of the New Year's holiday.
A vegetable soup specific to New Year's celebrations.
Lit. gate-pines (usually in pairs on either side of an entrance).
A Shinto altarpiece or household shrine decoration associated with the New Year.
A Chinese mythological equivalent for the Western Elysian Fields.
A Shinto offering for the New Year; the mirror-shape is associated with the Sun Goddess, the mythological ancestor of the Japanese islands and people.
Gifts to children, like 'Christmas money'.
At New Year's time.
Of beasts of burden, carts, boats, trucks, etc.
Especially for and popular at New Year's time; usually refers to the 'poem cards' based on the Hyakunin isshu, an anthology of 100 classical tanka poem.
A girls' game traditionally played at New Year's.
Colorful string balls; typical of a New Year's game. (Not to be confused with the Western game of handball.)
A good luck charm from a Shinto shrine.
A comedian and his straight man.
A ritual pageant.
Lit. 'young water'; first water drawn on New Year's Day.
Medicinal, traditionally eaten on 7 Jan to promote health in the coming year.

One of the oldest Japanese traditions, recorded in the earliest literature. Retains its meaning today, even though the New Year and beginning of spring no longer coincide. The 'greens' are the 'seven herbs', above.
New Year's ornaments, on 15 Jan.
Lit. 'into the thicket'; on 16 Jan servants visit their old homes.
A seaweed
A broad-leaved evergreen.
